q.q: every time someone on here asks you what your favorite song you've made is you always respond with something like "I'd rather write a new better one" or something. q.a: construction of music recordings and videos is very intricate, and it's like building a house. This is not the part i refer to as the writing. the writing process i am referring to is entirely before any piece of contruction matierial is touced. before any of the actual audio recording / video contents are actually created. i must know how the song/video goes, completely. every word, every melody note, and every important chord. and the exact tempo, and the exact sequence, and the exact road map all the way until the end. and therefore as a by product of that i therefore also know almost exactly how long it will play. This still leaves room for tremendous amounts of detail. All the details really. the writing process is getting everything EXCEPT the details. That's because when you are constructing the house, (or making the recording, or creating the video graphics), there are SO MANY things to take care of and worry about, just in terms of what materials you use, what details to put, besically that's when the paint actually hits. There are so many things to deal with and worry about there, i have found out that you CAN NOT be unsure of *how the song goes*

q.q: i wanna share some thoughts. when asked what is my religion,

i usually try to reply that i have some personal spiritual practices. it's weird because the word religion has other connotations which have nothing to do with what i do, such as...

community: what i do is completely personal and probably only makes sense to myself. i can share it with people i trust if i want to because it's important to me, but it's an individual practice.

god, God or gods: i do have gods, but i don't think i treat them the same way as most religions do. the way i see it is, they exist in my mind but not in actual material reality, that would feel silly to me. anyway, i think you don't actually need gods for your religion or spiritual beliefs to exist, you can structure what is sacred to you in other types of images. it's when you end up symbolizing what's sacred to you as characters, that we usually end up calling them gods. or you can decide to cal l god th e whole reality itself, that might strike you as a sensible way of looking at the world.

i feel like the question "what is your religion?" could be understood as "what is your truth?", and that is not something that may be simple to explain.

Personally, I feel like ever since I got deep into creative writing, I've been giving wittier and more descriptive responses in conversations with my friends and family, just by writing characters who say witty and descriptive responses.

q.a: if someone says 'waffles or pancakes', and nothing else, that is only a fragment of a question. they would need to say 'what' they are asking whether is pancakes or waffles. like if they showed me an item, and then said 'pancakes or waffles', then i would assumedly try to decide whether that item seems to be pancakes or waffles. Or, if they played me an audio sound, and then said 'pancakes or waffles', i would presumably be supposed to figure out if the sound is pancakes or waffles. When they say "pancakes or waffles", with absolutely no context, it presents a mostly impossible situation for me. so, given that the context is totally missing, sometimes rather than let the question hang frozen in contextlessness, i might make up my own context entirely, because they gave me absolutely nothing. so in this case, i made up the context as if the person was wondering which offered more leg room, pancakes or waffles, and also i made up the fact that the persons legs are quite small. so, in that way, i treated the horrible emptiness like a blank canvas. and i take blank canvases very seriously

q.a: i'll tell you the way i went through it. my plan, when i was at the exact same stage as you, is to go through them in order. talk/discuss (record the discussion also) the item at hand and determine where it's at. discuss its origins, discuss your first reactions, impressions, think about its origins, .... contemplate its place in the universe , ... and imagine whether you think it's worth it for it to exist / be finished. if you genuinely determine it's worth it, then start pursuing the next steps. determine what piece of it you have. is it the middle? beginning? something else? if it's the beginning, then your next task is to come up with the next part. this is best done by sheer runthroughs, and cut off right at the end, and listen very closely if the next bit will present itself. it can also be good to think process of elimination. what do you know it will and won't be? (categorically). i.e. will be a zebra/pony ride, or will it not be a zebra/pony ride. etc.... that could narrow it down. and again, continue raw runthroughs and cut off at end. If the initial idea was in the middle, that's probably just a lot of process of elimination. Once you have a significant development done on that item, document/date your progress and move to the next one. Then, aftar about 6 months of doing this (writing a little bit on each item) ... then, organize all the items into a new order, by % completed. appraise them all by % complete you think they are (estimation) and re-sort the list. Then, look at the top group (90 to 99% completed). choose (genuinely, without random assistance) 1 item from that group. Your next task is to finish the writing on that item. when i say 'finish the writing' i mean know how it goes from beginning to end. know all the bars, how many bars, all melody/lyric, chords, ... whatever constitutes your idea of a song in your mind, finish it so you know all that. mark it done. then go to the next group (80 to 89%). do the same thing. pick one, finish it. keep going like this, to the 70s, 60s, etc, all the way down, finishing (writing) 1 item per group. go around the group 2 or 3 times. Now, it's time to record. take the entire list, it doesn't matter what order, but preferably chronological. go through the list, (this will take a day or two) for each song, check how the song goes (properly consult all your documentation for it, read it, play it, check out all samples, etc. fully check how it goes, even if you think you vaguely remember. look it up for real.) then decide 'would i be excited to record this' or 'would i not be excited to record this'? your list of 'yes's can be as long as you want, so don't worry about 'to the exclusion of all other' just yet, just ask yourself would you be excited on some planet in some universe to record this one. if yes, then add it to a list (this is the semi-finals for recording selection list). Continue going through the entire master items list and add all the ones you would be excited to do. Then, as soon as you've gone through the entire list, IMMEDIATELY numberize the semi-finals list and make a random selection (using computer, like random.org. It is important that you do this immediately when completing the semi-finals list. Do not go around a second time. whenever i've gone for a second round of elimination, i often end up actually eliminating all of them. Trust your feelings in the first round. and immediately put it up for randomization (pick 1 out of the semi-finals, entirely computer assisted.) The one it chooses, that's the one. You should have already sufficiently eliminated any that are actually wrong for any reason. so you must trust this choice. And do it! This means, because you're working with a list of mixed completion levels, in many cases you will have to first finish the writing. then get to the recording. in cases of 100%, go still do writing verification. open the files, think and consider it, decide if the 100% appraisal holds up. if it doesn't, know that you are required to make a decision 1 way or another as to how to finish it, if not already. Then record it. that's the only thing you work on until the recording is done. and remember, if you get hung up because you think you 'can't make it good enough', remember to finish it anyway and accept your bonus: which is you'll automatically be better next time. then continue to do recording and continue to do it until you start to feel like it's getting so good it makes you angry that not enough people are hearing it. then start opening up some social media accounts,

Are there any recommendable checks, measures, bits of discipline to make this whole process workable?

q.a: i don't know any specific sources, but i can be a source. if you want to learn to read notation, i will probably want to start you off with rhythms. time goes forward from line to line. the first thing you want to do is understand beats. it's just like a steady ticking clock that ticks along with the beat all the way through a song. listen to some songs, and see if you can tap your foot along to the beat. also be aware that music notation flows left to right, and then down to the next line. left to right, next line, left to right, etc. just like the words on this page. let me know when you have found the beat for some of your favorite songs. if you look at the cowbell part for the second verse of my song 'hallelujah', that is an example of the beat. you might say i am hitting the cowbell 'on the beat'. it usually stays the same for the whole song. the songs you pick may have a faster or slower beat from that, but most of them will probably be slightly faster, because that song has a relatively slow tempo. see if you can find the beat for some of your favorite songs, then i will see if i can tell you what's necessary to start understanding what happens on the page

q.q: It seems kind of dumb but my entire understanding of music and how i made sense of harmony came from root voicing block chords. But it's a serious rut. because obviously listening to your music there's a whole other thing to it which i interpret as "sparse-ness". Meaning EVERY note can MATTER and hold serious weight leading into wherever it goes. I just suppose this anyway...But for Years i couldn't begin to understand the logic to it. Meanwhile, I plowed through a harmony book. learned about all these cool chords Outside of the major scale that relate to the major scale. and implement them as well as fun time signatures into my work in a way that was organic and good. but i still do the dumb chord thing. and so like a year ago to h opefully  evolve and understand why I needed to change I started transcribing pop songs i enjoyed, completely. even maracas for like one upbeat on a single measure. So I think my ear is getting better because of that. i mean it might be ridiculous. considering i'm sure even the players for "running on empty"-jackson browne were looking at Much simpler charts than what they actually played. but i insist on doing it. Anyway! So all this time passes in my development and i still feel like i'd immediately fall face first if i were let out in the real world because of the chord thing.

q.q:
Right now in Australia we're dealing with our worst fires in recorded history and have lost almost 500 million animals and quite a few people, including volunteer firefighters. Over 14 million acres have been burnt. That's twice the size of Belgium. It's scary and hard to comprehend.
I'm lucky enough not to be affected but I feel dreadful not being able to help. I've managed to donate $130 dollars but it feels like nothing. It wouldnt even scratch the surface. It might put fuel in 2 cars with small tanks. It can't buy even a cheap firefighting pump, or hardly any livestock feed, or other necessities like that. It brings me to tears knowing I'm capable of so little because of my lack of money. Sometimes I wish I were rich, purely for the ability to fucking help more and make an actual difference.
Sorry, I just had to vent a bit. I can't express these feelings to people around me because ffs, these selfish issues are nothing compared with w hat the people affected are dealing with and it's childish of me to think like this. Wtf can I do? I'm just one person.

q.q: Though when you go to sleep, you have then 'lost' consciousness. Well, where did it go? I'm assuming that this means that everything was sort of 'separate' for a while, which makes sense, because a lot of the brain majorly either slows down or stops completely while asleep, and thus the whole is not there. But it's death that is weird. When you sleep, it can feel like an instant from when you fell asleep to when you woke, but when you die, that instant of being conscious again will (in theory) never come.

q.a: you've presented various different ideas here, getting mind blown by the idea of concsiousness, yes that i can relate to wholly. you infered somehow that it's the end of all consciousness when you die, and i didn't really gather where you were coming from with that. and you said you want to be remembered, yes i can relate to that, as i think all of us can
q.q:
You won't know anything, you won't be anything, and it's that thought that scares me. And it's that thought in which pushes me to slow down on lif e and re ally focus on the parts I enjoy rather than trying to do things that will get me material things, I don't want a job, I just want to make things, and I just want to be remembered, at least in some capacity, at least for a little while. Sorry if I rambled on for a bit too long there, but I was just wondering if you had any sort of insight or if you have any similar ideas/thoughts at all?

Thanks for reading.

q.a: 36 is the range of the random number picked. has to be between 0 and 35. it's going to be converted to letters/numbers. so that's how many choices there are (26 letters, and 10 numbers). the '-1' means you start the variable "n" at -1. the (\d|\D)(?=,) is regex to search for every letter/number with a comma after. the x%n% means literally the letter x followed by whatever value n currently is. so if n is 5 then x%n% would be x5
